what: Impute new unseen data using a trained imputer
title: Imputing newdata with a saved mixgb imputer
text: First can split nhanes3_newborn dataset training data test data. can use training data obtain m imputed datasets save imputation models. achieve , users need set save.models = TRUE. default save.vars = NULL, imputation models variables missing data training data saved. However, unseen data may also missing values variables. Users can comprehensive saving models variables setting save.vars = colnames(train.data). Note take much longer need train save model variable. users confident certain variables missing values new data, recommend specifying names indices variables save.vars instead saving models variables. can extract m imputed datasets saved imputer object $imputed.data. impute new data saved imputer object, use impute_new() function. User can also specify whether use new data initial imputation. default, initial.newdata = FALSE, use information training data initially impute new data. New data imputed saved models. process considerably faster don’t need build imputation models . PMM used trained imputer, predicted values missing entries new dataset matched donors training data. Users can also set number donors PMM imputing new data. default, pmm.k = NULL , means setting training object used. Similarly, users can set number imputed datasets m. Note value smaller equal m trained imputer. specified, use m value trained imputer.
code: library(mixgb) data("nhanes3_newborn") set.seed(2022) n <- nrow(nhanes3_newborn) idx <- sample(1:n, size = round(0.7 * n), replace = FALSE) train.data <- nhanes3_newborn[idx, ] test.data <- nhanes3_newborn[-idx, ] MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = train.data) mixgb.obj <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1, save.models = TRUE, save.vars = NULL) #> mixgb with bootstrap: saving models and imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 imputed.traindata <- mixgb.obj$imputed.data #the 5th imputed dataset head(imputed.traindata[[5]]) #>    HSHSIZER HSAGEIR HSSEX DMARACER DMAETHNR DMARETHN BMPHEAD BMPRECUM BMPSB1 #> 1:        7       2     1        1        1        3    42.4     66.7    7.8 #> 2:        4       3     2        2        3        2    42.6     67.1    8.8 #> 3:        3       9     2        2        3        2    46.5     64.3    8.6 #> 4:        3       9     2        1        3        1    46.2     68.5   10.8 #> 5:        5       4     1        1        3        1    44.7     63.0    6.0 #> 6:        5      10     1        1        3        1    45.2     72.0    5.4 #>    BMPSB2 BMPTR1 BMPTR2 BMPWT DMPPIR HFF1 HYD1 #> 1:    8.0    8.8    9.5  7.60  1.701    2    1 #> 2:    8.8   13.3   12.2  8.70  0.102    2    1 #> 3:    8.0   10.4    9.2  8.00  0.359    1    3 #> 4:   10.0   16.6   16.0  8.98  0.561    1    3 #> 5:    5.8    9.0    9.0  7.60  2.379    2    1 #> 6:    5.4    9.2    9.4  9.00  2.173    2    2 imputed.testdata <- impute_new(object = mixgb.obj, newdata = test.data)  #> Imputing new data with mixgb:  set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 imputed.testdata <- impute_new(object = mixgb.obj, newdata = test.data, initial.newdata = FALSE, pmm.k = 3, m = 4) #> Imputing new data with mixgb:  set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Mixgb offers scalable solution imputing large datasets using XGBoost, bootstrapping predictive mean matching. Mixgb built Fully Conditional Specification (FCS), XGBoost imputation models built incomplete variable. Mixgb can automatically handle different types variables users need encode categorical variables . Users can also choose different settings regarding bootstrapping types predictive mean matching enhance imputation performance.

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: first load mixgb package nhanes3_newborn dataset, contains 16 variables various types (integer/numeric/factor/ordinal factor). 9 variables missing values. impute dataset, first need set Mixgb imputer choice settings leave default. Note need convert data dgCMatrix one-hot coding format. package convert automatically. Variables following types: numeric, integer, factor ordinal factor. Except data, arguments Mixgb$new( ) either hyperparameters verbose settings XGBoost training.

DMARACER DMAETHNR DMARETHN  BMPHEAD BMPRECUM  #>        0        0        0        0        0        0      124      114  #>   BMPSB1   BMPSB2   BMPTR1   BMPTR2    BMPWT   DMPPIR     HFF1     HYD1  #>      161      169      124      167      117      192        7        0  #use mixgb with default settings MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn) imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1) #> mixgb with bootstrap: imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 #Set up mixgb imputer with chosen settings params = list(max_depth = 6,                gamma = 0.1,                eta = 0.3,     tree_method = "auto",                gpu_id = 0,                predictor = "auto")  MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn, xgb.params = params, nrounds = 100, early_stopping_rounds = 1, print_every_n = 1, verbose = 0)

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Imputation performance can affected hyperparameter settings. may seem daunting tune large set hyperparameters, often can narrow search many hyperparameters correlated. package, function mixgb_cv() tune nrounds. default nrounds value XGBoost, need specify . default nrounds mixgb 50. However, recommend using mixgb_cv() find optimal nrounds first. default, mixgb_cv() randomly choose incomplete variable response build XGBoost model variables using complete cases dataset. Therefore, run mixgb_cv() likely return different results. Users can also specify response covariates argument response select_covariates, respectively. Since results returned mixgb_cv() mostly less 20, ’ll set nrounds = 20 imputer. now use imputer obtain m imputed datasets, stored list m data tables. m = 1, single imputation undertaken. Users can also specify number imputation iterations maxit.

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: can also customise imputation settings: Whether use bootstrapping types predictive mean matching number donors predictive mean matching Whether convert ordinal factors integer (imputation process faster) Initial imputation methods different types variables
code: imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1,  bootstrap = TRUE,                              pmm.type = "auto", pmm.k = 5,                               ordinalAsInteger = TRUE,                              initial.num = "normal", initial.int = "sample", initial.fac = "mode") #> mixgb with bootstrap: imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5

text: dataset ordinal factors, imputation process sped converting integers. nhanes3_newborn data, one ordinal factor, can still see imputation time smaller ordinalAsInteger = TRUE. m maxit larger, difference even obvious. Note ordinalAsInteger = TRUE , class ordinal factors imputed datasets also integer. recommend use default PMM setting pmm.type = "auto", impute numeric integer variables PMM (type 2) impute categorical variables without PMM. don’t apply PMM integer variables, missing values may imputed numeric. Sometimes can problematic, especially integers actually converted ordinal factors. Therefore, pmm.type = NULL disabled ordinalAsInteger = TRUE .
code: system.time(imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1,ordinalAsInteger = FALSE)) #> mixgb with bootstrap: imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 #>    user  system elapsed  #>   7.391   1.018   6.795  system.time(imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1,ordinalAsInteger = TRUE)) #> mixgb with bootstrap: imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 #>    user  system elapsed  #>   6.658   1.112   6.303

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: demonstrate functions using nhanes3_newborn dataset. original data, almost missing values occurred numeric variables. seven observations missing binary factor variable HFF1 . order visualize imputed values types variables, create extra missing values HSHSIZER (integer), HSAGEIR (integer), HSSEX (binary factor), DMARETHN (multiclass factor) HYD1 (Ordinal factor) MCAR. impute dataset using mixgb default settings. list five imputed datasets assigned imputed.data. dimension imputed dataset original data. can check actual imputed values single variable using function show_var(). return data.table m columns, column contains one set imputed values specified variable. imputed values missing entries shown.
code: library(mixgb) data("nhanes3_newborn") colSums(is.na(nhanes3_newborn)) #> HSHSIZER  HSAGEIR    HSSEX DMARACER DMAETHNR DMARETHN  BMPHEAD BMPRECUM  #>        0        0        0        0        0        0      124      114  #>   BMPSB1   BMPSB2   BMPTR1   BMPTR2    BMPWT   DMPPIR     HFF1     HYD1  #>      161      169      124      167      117      192        7        0 withNA.df<-createNA(data=nhanes3_newborn, var.names = c("HSHSIZER","HSAGEIR","HSSEX","DMARETHN","HYD1"), p = 0.1) colSums(is.na(withNA.df)) #> HSHSIZER  HSAGEIR    HSSEX DMARACER DMAETHNR DMARETHN  BMPHEAD BMPRECUM  #>      211      211      211        0        0      211      124      114  #>   BMPSB1   BMPSB2   BMPTR1   BMPTR2    BMPWT   DMPPIR     HFF1     HYD1  #>      161      169      124      167      117      192        7      211 MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = withNA.df) imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5) #> mixgb with bootstrap: imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 show_var(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.name="BMPHEAD",original.data = withNA.df) #>        m1   m2   m3   m4   m5 #>   1: 45.2 35.7 46.8 44.7 47.3 #>   2: 44.0 46.6 44.8 44.1 46.0 #>   3: 43.9 44.9 42.9 43.0 42.8 #>   4: 45.1 44.3 47.6 46.3 46.3 #>   5: 44.0 45.2 45.2 45.3 42.0 #>  ---                          #> 120: 46.5 44.9 45.3 45.2 45.3 #> 121: 45.8 46.4 44.0 42.1 44.9 #> 122: 42.6 42.5 43.2 42.1 41.3 #> 123: 44.7 43.8 45.1 44.7 42.9 #> 124: 45.5 46.3 47.3 47.2 44.6  show_var(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.name="HFF1",original.data = withNA.df) #>    m1 m2 m3 m4 m5 #> 1:  2  1  1  1  2 #> 2:  1  1  2  1  1 #> 3:  2  2  1  2  1 #> 4:  1  1  1  1  2 #> 5:  2  2  2  2  2 #> 6:  2  2  2  2  2 #> 7:  2  2  2  1  2

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: mixgb package provides following visual diagnostics functions: Single variable: plot_hist(), plot_box(), plot_bar() ; Two variables: plot_2num(), plot_2fac(), plot_1num1fac() ; Three variables: plot_2num1fac(), plot_1num2fac(). function return m+1 panels compare observed data m sets actual imputed values.

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: imputations missing entries specified variable ploted panels m1 m5. variable fully observed, return error.

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: can plot imputed numeric variable histogram boxplot. plot_hist(): plot histograms density curves. Histograms good displaying distribution numeric data. Users can identify unusual pattern imputed values shapes. MCAR, expect distribution imputed values observed ones. MAR, distributions observed imputed values can quite different. However, still worth plotting imputed data odd values may indicate imputation procedure unsatisfactory.  plot_box(): plot box plots overlaying data points. Users can use plot_box() compare median, lower upper quantiles imputed values observed ones. Also, can see difference number missing values observed values specified variable.
code: plot_hist(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num="BMPHEAD",original.data = withNA.df) plot_box(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num="BMPHEAD",original.data = withNA.df)

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: plot_bar(): plot bar plots proportion level factor shown plot_bar().
code: plot_bar(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.fac="HSSEX",original.data = withNA.df) plot_bar(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.fac="DMARETHN",original.data = withNA.df)

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: producing plot, integer variable can treated either numeric factor. Users can plot imputed integer variable according preferences using following functions: plot_hist(): plot histograms density curves plot_box(): plot box plot overlaying data points plot_bar(): plot bar plot (treat integer variable factor)
code: plot_hist(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num="HSHSIZER",original.data = withNA.df) plot_box(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num="HSHSIZER",original.data = withNA.df) plot_bar(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.fac="HSHSIZER",original.data = withNA.df)

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: mixgb imputer convert ordinal factor original.data integers default. speed imputation process, users need decide whether transform back. case, can just plot imputed values integers (see Section 2.1.3). users set ordinalAsInteger = FALSE imputer, can plot ordinal factors factors. (see Section 2.1.2).
code: plot_bar(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.fac="HYD1",original.data = withNA.df) plot_hist(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num="HYD1",original.data = withNA.df) plot_box(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num="HYD1",original.data = withNA.df)

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: plot multiply imputed values two variables, least one incomplete original data. panels m1 m5, missing data either occurs either one variables.

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: can plot scatter plots two numeric variables using plot_2num(). can specify name numeric variable x-axis var.x , another numeric variable y-axis var.y. NA.condition represents following types missing variables. .observed: var.x andvar.y observed. appears first panel - Observed . .missing: Imputed values var.x var.y originally missing; x.missing: Imputed values var.x originally missing var.y isn’t; y.missing: Imputed values var.y originally missing var.x isn’t.
code: plot_2num(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x="BMPHEAD",var.y="BMPRECUM",original.data = withNA.df)

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: can plot numeric variable versus factor using plot_1num1fac(). output box plot overlaying points. Users need specify numeric variable var.num factor var.fac. NA.condition similar definition Section 2.2.1.
code: plot_1num1fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num="BMPHEAD",var.fac="HSSEX",original.data = withNA.df)

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: can plot bar plots show relationship two factors using plot_2fac(). Note function requires least one variables incomplete original dataset.
code: plot_2fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.fac1="HYD1",var.fac2="HFF1",original.data = withNA.df)

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: can use plot_2num() plot numeric variable versus integer variable. Note plots look different swap variables var.x var.y.   treat integer variable factor, can use plot_1num1fac() .
code: plot_2num(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x="BMPHEAD",var.y="HSAGEIR",original.data = withNA.df) plot_2num(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x="HSAGEIR",var.y="BMPHEAD",original.data = withNA.df) plot_1num1fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num="BMPHEAD",var.fac="HSAGEIR",original.data = withNA.df)

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: can plot two variables integer type using either plot_2num() ,plot_1num1fac() plot_2fac(). Users choose plotting functions based nature variable. example, integer variable age data ranging 0 110, may easier treat age numeric rather factor. hand, integer variable several distinct values (e.g. 1,2,3), may better treat factor plotting. dataset, two variable integer type-HSHSIZER(household size) HSAGEIR(baby’s age ranging 2 11 months). expect obvious relation two, plot anyway.
code: plot_2num(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x="HSAGEIR",var.y="HSHSIZER",original.data = withNA.df) plot_2num(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x="HSHSIZER",var.y="HSAGEIR",original.data = withNA.df) plot_1num1fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num="HSAGEIR",var.fac="HSHSIZER",original.data = withNA.df) plot_1num1fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num="HSHSIZER",var.fac="HSAGEIR",original.data = withNA.df) plot_2fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.fac1="HSHSIZER",var.fac2="HSAGEIR",original.data = withNA.df)

what: 2.3.1 Two numeric variables conditional on one factor
title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: can generate conditional scatter plots two numeric variables using plot_2num1fac() . variable x-axis specified var.x, y-axis one var.y . factor want conditional con.fac. three variables, \(2^3\) different types missing patterns, consisting possible combinations zero three variables missing. However, hard differentiate 8 types missingness plots, especially case dataset small. Therefore, choose show following three types NA.condition plot. NA.condition represents following types missing variables. .observed: Observations three variables observed. appears first panel - Observed . con.fac.observed: Imputed values con.fac originally observed. (points originally missing either var.x var.y ) con.fac.missing: imputed values con.fac originally missing. (points can originally observed, missing either var.x var.y )   want treat integer variables numeric, can put either var.x var.y. example, HSAGEIR integer variable values ranging 2 11.
code: plot_2num1fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x="BMPHEAD",var.y="BMPRECUM",con.fac="HFF1",original.data = withNA.df) plot_2num1fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x="BMPHEAD",var.y="BMPRECUM",con.fac="DMARETHN",original.data = withNA.df) plot_2num1fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x="HSAGEIR",var.y="BMPRECUM",con.fac="DMARETHN",original.data = withNA.df)

what: 2.3.2 One numeric variable and one factor conditional on another factor
title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: plot_1num2fac() generate boxplots overlaying data points one numeric variable vs factor, conditional another factor.
code: plot_1num2fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.fac="DMARETHN",var.num="BMPRECUM",con.fac="HSSEX",original.data = withNA.df)

title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: default, observed panel gray m panels use ggplot2’s default color scheme.  can change colors providing vector color hex codes argument color.pal. example, can use one colorblind-friendly palette Set2 R package RColorBrewer. Note m imputed datasets, need m+1 hex codes also display Observed panel.  Otherwise, can provide vector R’s built-color names.  useful R colors names cheat-sheet created Dr Ying Wei. http://www.stat.columbia.edu/\~tzheng/files/Rcolor.pdf
code: plot_2num(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x="BMPHEAD",var.y="BMPRECUM",original.data = withNA.df,color.pal = NULL) library(RColorBrewer) color.codes<-brewer.pal(n=6,name = "Set2") color.codes #> [1] "#66C2A5" "#FC8D62" "#8DA0CB" "#E78AC3" "#A6D854" "#FFD92F"    plot_2num(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x="BMPHEAD",var.y="BMPRECUM",original.data = withNA.df,color.pal = color.codes) color.names<-c("gray50","coral2","goldenrod3","darkolivegreen4","slateblue1","plum3")    plot_2num(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x="BMPHEAD",var.y="BMPRECUM",original.data = withNA.df,color.pal = color.names)

what: 4 Plot multiply imputed data from other packages
title: Visual diagnostics for multiply imputed values
text: can also plot multiply imputed datasets obtaining packages, mice. example using nhanes2 data mice. Note dataset quite small, 25 rows 4 columns (age, bmi, hyp chl). 9, 8 10 missing values variables bmi, hyp chl respectively. Imputed values volatile dataset small.
code: library(mice) dim(nhanes2) #> [1] 25  4 colSums(is.na(nhanes2)) #> age bmi hyp chl  #>   0   9   8  10   imp<-mice(data=nhanes2,m=5,printFlag = FALSE) mice.data<-complete(imp,action="all")  plot_hist(imputation.list = mice.data,var.num = "bmi",original.data = nhanes2) plot_box(imputation.list = mice.data,var.num = "chl",original.data = nhanes2) plot_bar(imputation.list = mice.data,var.fac = "hyp",original.data = nhanes2) plot_2num(imputation.list = mice.data,var.x = "bmi",var.y="chl",original.data = nhanes2) plot_1num1fac(imputation.list = mice.data,var.num = "chl",var.fac ="hyp",original.data = nhanes2) plot_2num1fac(imputation.list = mice.data,var.x = "chl",var.y="bmi",con.fac="age",original.data = nhanes2) plot_2num1fac(imputation.list = mice.data,var.x = "chl",var.y="bmi",con.fac="hyp",original.data = nhanes2)

text: mixgb scalable multiple imputation framework based XGBoost, bootstrapping predictive mean matching. proposed framework implemented R package mixgb. shown framework obtains less biased estimates reflects appropriate imputation variability, achieving high computational efficiency. details, please check paper https://arxiv.org/abs/2106.01574. (package revised updated since preprint posted. Simulation code original supplementary files may run expected. Revised paper adapted code updated soon.)

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: highly recommended clean check data imputation. common issues: Data data frame. ID removed Missing values coded NA NaN Inf -Inf allowed Empty cells coded NA sensible values Variables “character” type converted “factor” instead Variables “factor” type least two levels function data_clean() can preliminary check fix obvious problems. However, fix issues related data quality.
code: library(mixgb) cleanWithNA.df <- data_clean(rawdata)

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: first load mixgb package nhanes3_newborn dataset, contains 16 variables various types (integer/numeric/factor/ordinal factor). 9 variables missing values. impute dataset, first need set Mixgb imputer choice settings leave default. Note need convert data dgCMatrix one-hot coding format. package convert automatically. Variables following types: numeric, integer, factor ordinal factor. Except data, arguments Mixgb$new( ) either hyperparameters verbose settings XGBoost training.
code: library(mixgb) data(nhanes3_newborn) colSums(is.na(nhanes3_newborn)) #> HSHSIZER  HSAGEIR    HSSEX DMARACER DMAETHNR DMARETHN  BMPHEAD BMPRECUM  #>        0        0        0        0        0        0      124      114  #>   BMPSB1   BMPSB2   BMPTR1   BMPTR2    BMPWT   DMPPIR     HFF1     HYD1  #>      161      169      124      167      117      192        7        0 # use mixgb with default settings MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn) imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1) # Set up mixgb imputer with chosen settings params = list(max_depth = 6, gamma = 0.1, eta = 0.3, min_child_weight = 1,     subsample = 1, colsample_bytree = 1, colsample_bylevel = 1,     colsample_bynode = 1, nthread = 4, tree_method = "auto",     gpu_id = 0, predictor = "auto")  MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn, xgb.params = params,     nrounds = 100, early_stopping_rounds = 1, print_every_n = 1,     verbose = 0)

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Imputation performance can affected hyperparameter settings. may seem daunting tune large set hyperparameters, often can narrow search many hyperparameters correlated. package, function mixgb_cv() tune nrounds. default nrounds value XGBoost, need specify . default nrounds mixgb 50. However, recommend using mixgb_cv() find optimal nrounds first. default, mixgb_cv() randomly choose incomplete variable response build XGBoost model variables using complete cases dataset. Therefore, run mixgb_cv() likely return different results. Users can also specify response covariates argument response select_covariates, respectively. Since results returned mixgb_cv() mostly less 20, ’ll set nrounds = 20 imputer. now use imputer obtain m imputed datasets, stored list m data tables. m = 1, single imputation undertaken. Users can also specify number imputation iterations maxit.
code: optimal.nrounds <- mixgb_cv(data = nhanes3_newborn, verbose = FALSE) optimal.nrounds$response #> [1] "BMPHEAD" optimal.nrounds$best.nrounds #> [1] 18 optimal.nrounds <- mixgb_cv(data = nhanes3_newborn, nfold = 10,     nrounds = 100, early_stopping_rounds = 1, response = "BMPHEAD",     select_covariates = c("HSHSIZER", "HSAGEIR", "HSSEX", "DMARETHN",         "BMPRECUM", "BMPSB1", "BMPSB2", "BMPTR1", "BMPTR2", "BMPWT",         "DMPPIR", "HFF1", "HYD1"), verbose = FALSE)  optimal.nrounds$best.nrounds #> [1] 18 MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn, nrounds = 20) imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1)

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: can also customise imputation settings: Whether use bootstrapping types predictive mean matching number donors predictive mean matching Whether convert ordinal factors integer (imputation process faster) Initial imputation methods different types variables
code: imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1, bootstrap = TRUE,     pmm.type = "auto", pmm.k = 5, ordinalAsInteger = TRUE, initial.num = "normal",     initial.int = "sample", initial.fac = "mode")

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: important assess plausibility imputations analysis. mixgb package provides several visual diagnostic functions using ggplot2 compare multiply imputed values versus observed data. demonstrate functions using nhanes3_newborn dataset. original data, almost missing values occurred numeric variables. seven observations missing binary factor variable HFF1 . order visualize imputed values types variables, create extra missing values HSHSIZER (integer), HSAGEIR (integer), HSSEX (binary factor), DMARETHN (multiclass factor) HYD1 (Ordinal factor) MCAR. impute dataset using mixgb default settings. list five imputed datasets assigned imputed.data. dimension imputed dataset original data. mixgb package provides following visual diagnostics functions: Single variable: plot_hist(), plot_box(), plot_bar() ; Two variables: plot_2num(), plot_2fac(), plot_1num1fac() ; Three variables: plot_2num1fac(), plot_1num2fac(). function return m+1 panels compare observed data m sets actual imputed values. examples. details, please check vignettes Visual-diagnostics.
code: withNA.df <- createNA(data = nhanes3_newborn, var.names = c("HSHSIZER", "HSAGEIR", "HSSEX", "DMARETHN", "HYD1"), p = 0.1) colSums(is.na(withNA.df)) #> HSHSIZER HSAGEIR HSSEX DMARACER DMAETHNR DMARETHN BMPHEAD BMPRECUM #> 211 211 211 0 0 211 124 114 #> BMPSB1 BMPSB2 BMPTR1 BMPTR2 BMPWT DMPPIR HFF1 HYD1 #> 161 169 124 167 117 192 7 211 MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = withNA.df) imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5) #> mixgb with bootstrap: imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 ```r plot_hist(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num = "BMPHEAD", original.data = withNA.df) ``` ```r plot_2num(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x = "BMPHEAD", var.y = "BMPRECUM", original.data = withNA.df) ``` ```r plot_2num(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.x = "HSAGEIR", var.y = "BMPHEAD", original.data = withNA.df) ``` ```r plot_1num1fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.num = "BMPHEAD", var.fac = "HSSEX", original.data = withNA.df) ``` ```r plot_2fac(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.fac1 = "HYD1", var.fac2 = "HSSEX", original.data = withNA.df) ```

what: Impute new unseen data using a trained imputer
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: First can split nhanes3_newborn dataset training data test data. can use training data obtain m imputed datasets save imputation models. achieve , users need set save.models = TRUE. default save.vars = NULL, imputation models variables missing data training data saved. However, unseen data may also missing values variables. Users can comprehensive saving models variables setting save.vars = colnames(train.data). Note take much longer need train save model variable. users confident certain variables missing values new data, recommend specifying names indices variables save.vars instead saving models variables. can extract m imputed datasets saved imputer object $imputed.data. impute new data saved imputer object, use impute_new() function. User can also specify whether use new data initial imputation. default, initial.newdata = FALSE, use information training data initially impute new data. New data imputed saved models. process considerably faster don’t need build imputation models . PMM used trained imputer, predicted values missing entries new dataset matched donors training data. Users can also set number donors PMM imputing new data. default, pmm.k = NULL , means setting training object used. Similarly, users can set number imputed datasets m. Note value smaller equal m trained imputer. specified, use m value trained imputer.
code: library(mixgb) data("nhanes3_newborn") set.seed(2022) n <- nrow(nhanes3_newborn) idx <- sample(1:n, size = round(0.7 * n), replace = FALSE) train.data <- nhanes3_newborn[idx, ] test.data <- nhanes3_newborn[-idx, ] MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = train.data) mixgb.obj <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1, save.models = TRUE,     save.vars = NULL) imputed.traindata <- mixgb.obj$imputed.data imputed.testdata <- impute_new(object = mixgb.obj, newdata = test.data) imputed.testdata <- impute_new(object = mixgb.obj, newdata = test.data,     initial.newdata = FALSE, pmm.k = 3, m = 4)

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost

Note users install R package xgboost GPU support first. xgboost R package pre-built binary Linux x86_64 GPU supportcan downloaded release page https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/releases/tag/v1.4.0 package can installed running following commands: ``` # Install dependencies $ R -q -e “install.packages(c(‘data.table’, ‘jsonlite’))”

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: $ R CMD INSTALL ./xgboost_r_gpu_linux.tar.gz Users just need specify tree_method = "gpu_list" params list setting Mixgb imputer. GPU-realted arguments include gpu_id predictor. default, gpu_id = 0 predictor = "auto".
code: Then users can install package `mixgb` in R.    ```r devtools::install_github("agnesdeng/mixgb") library(mixgb) params = list(max_depth = 6, gamma = 0.1, eta = 0.3, min_child_weight = 1,     subsample = 1, colsample_bytree = 1, colsample_bylevel = 1,     colsample_bynode = 1, nthread = 4, tree_method = "gpu_list",     gpu_id = 0, predictor = "auto")  MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(withNA.df, xgb.params = params)  mixgb.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5)

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
code: Mixgb$impute(   m = 5,   maxit = 1,   bootstrap = TRUE,   pmm.type = "auto",   pmm.k = 5,   pmm.link = "prob",   ordinalAsInteger = TRUE,   initial.num = "normal",   initial.int = "mode",   initial.fac = "mode",   save.models = FALSE,   save.vars = NULL,   ... )

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
text: m number imputed datasets. Default: 5 maxit number imputation iterations. Default: 1 bootstrap Whether use bootstrapping multiple imputation. default, bootstrap = TRUE. FALSE, users recommended specify sampling-related hyperparameters XGBoost obtain imputations adequate variability. pmm.type types predictive mean matching (PMM). Possible values: NULL: Imputations without PMM; 0: Imputations PMM type 0; 1: Imputations PMM type 1; 2: Imputations PMM type 2; "auto" (Default): Imputations PMM type 2 numeric/integer variables; imputations without PMM categorical variables. pmm.k number donors predictive mean matching. Default: 5 pmm.link link predictive mean matching binary variables "prob" (Default): use probabilities; "logit": use logit values. ordinalAsInteger Whether convert ordinal factors integers. default setting ordinalAsInteger = TRUE can speed imputation process. initial.num Initial imputation method numeric type data: "normal" (Default); "mean"; "median"; "mode"; "sample". initial.int Initial imputation method integer type data: "mode" (Default); "sample". initial.fac Initial imputation method factor type data: "mode" (Default); "sample". save.models Whether save models imputing new data later . Default: FALSE save.vars Response models variables specified save.vars saved imputing new data. Can vector names indices. default, save.vars = NULL, response models variables missing values saved. save models, please specify save.vars = colnames(data). ... Extra arguments pass XGBoost

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
text: save.models = FALSE, return list m imputed datasets. save.models = TRUE, return object imputed datasets, saved models parameters.

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
code: if (FALSE) { #use default MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn) #obtain m multiply datasets without saving models imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5)  #obtain m multiply imputed datasets and save models for imputing new data later on imputed.obj <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, save.models = TRUE) }

code: if (FALSE) { set.seed(2022) n <- nrow(nhanes3_newborn) idx <- sample(1:n, size = round(0.7 * n), replace = FALSE) train.data <- nhanes3_newborn[idx, ] test.data <- nhanes3_newborn[-idx, ]  MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = train.data) imputed.obj <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, bootstrap = TRUE, save.models = TRUE) imputed.testdata <- impute_new(object = imputed.obj, newdata = test.data) }

what: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost — mixgb-package
title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost — mixgb-package
text: Mixgb offers scalable solution imputing large datasets using XGBoost, bootstrapping predictive mean matching. Mixgb built Fully Conditional Specification (FCS), XGBoost imputation models built incomplete variable. Mixgb can automatically handle different types variables users need encode categorical variables . Users can also choose different settings regarding bootstrapping predictive mean matching enhance imputation performance.

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost — mixgb-package

Fully conditional specification multivariate imputation. Journal Statistical Computation Simulation, 76(12), 1049-1064. van Buuren, S. (2018). Flexible Imputation Missing Data. Second Edition. Little, R. J. (1988). Missing-data adjustments large surveys. Journal Business & Economic Statistics, 6(3), 287. Efron, B. (1979). Bootstrap methods: Another look jackknife. Annals Statistics, 7(1).

NHANES III (1988-1994) newborn data — nhanes3_newborn
text: dataset extracted NHANES III (1988-1994) age class Newborn (1 year). Please note example dataset contains selected variables used demonstrating use R package mixgb. information NHANES III data can found https://wwwn.cdc.gov/Nchs/Data/Nhanes3/7a/doc/mimodels.pdf

title: NHANES III (1988-1994) newborn data — nhanes3_newborn
code: data(nhanes3_newborn)

title: NHANES III (1988-1994) newborn data — nhanes3_newborn
text: data frame 2107 rows 16 variables. Nine variables missing values. HSHSIZER Household size. integer variable 1 10. HSAGEIR Age interview (screener) - qty (months). integer variable 2 11. HSSEX Sex. factor variable levels 1 (Male) 2 (Female). DMARACER Race. factor variable levels 1 (White), 2 (Black) 3 (). DMAETHNR Ethnicity. factor variable levels 1 (Mexican-American), 2 (Hispanic) 3 (Hispanic). DMARETHN Race-ethnicity. factor variable levels 1 (Non-Hispanic white), 2 (Non-Hispanic black), 3 (Mexican-American) 4 (). BMPHEAD Head circumference (cm). Numeric. BMPRECUM Recumbent length (cm). Numeric. BMPSB1 First subscapular skinfold (mm). Numeric. BMPSB2 Second subscapular skinfold (mm). Numeric. BMPTR1 First triceps skinfold (mm). Numeric. BMPTR2 Second triceps skinfold (mm). Numeric. BMPWT Weight (kg). Numeric. DMPPIR Poverty income ratio. Numeric. HFF1 anyone lives smoke cigarettes home? factor variable levels 1 (Yes) 2 (). HYD1 health subject person general? ordinal factor levels 1 (Excellent), 2 (good), 3 (Good), 4 (Fair) 5 (Poor).
